Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Towards Green Communications Using an Information-Lens: Foundations of the Joint Design of Communication Strategies and Circuits

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project aims to develop a system-level theory of energy efficient communication that incorporates the energy consumed in transmission as well as in the supporting transmitter/receiver circuitry. The existing theoretical foundation that guides the design of practical communication systems -- traditional information theory -- focuses almost exclusively on the transmit energy. For many modern short-distance communication systems, however, the energy consumed in the processing circuitry dominates over the transmit energy. The proposed research will advance the existing theory and practice by examining flows of information in the supporting circuitry in order to obtain a fundamental understanding of total (transmit + circuit) energy. A three-layer approach will be adopted to reduce energy consumption: (i) The Foundational Layer for expanding the frontiers of traditional information theory by incorporating processing energy at the transmitting and receiving ends; (ii) The Design Layer for novel designs of strategies including error-correcting codes that minimize the total energy; and (iii) The Validation Layer for assessing the energy reductions for various applications through strategies proposed in the Design Layer.

Applications ranging from education, healthcare, manufacturing, and commerce today rely on uninterrupted and ubiquitous connectivity. Consequently, it has become increasingly important to keep the energy consumed in communication networks low, both for improving battery life of wireless devices and for sustainability of high-energy wired communication (such as ethernet links in data centers). Broadly speaking, the traditional design approach follows a "division-of-labor": the transmission strategy is first chosen to best approach the information-theoretic limits on minimum transmit energy, and then the most energy-efficient circuits are built to support the chosen strategy. The proposed research rethinks this division-of-labor by jointly designing the transmission strategy and circuits to maximize system-level energy efficiency. This research necessitates simplification and synthesis of concepts in communication, computation, and circuits. The project incorporates several educational and outreach efforts, including organizing interactive workshops for K-12 students and developing new material for both theoretical and experimental classes towards educating cross-disciplinary leaders not just in research, but also in industry where such education is essential for increased innovation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the Big Data era arrives, Information and Communication Technologies are increasingly using a substantial fraction of world's energy. For sustainable growth of Big Data analytics, the conducted research obtained novel strategies as well as fundamental limits on energy requirements, while keeping target reliability sufficiently high. 

The research addressed several long-standing problems at the intersection of communication and computing towards enabling reliable and efficient distributed sensing and computation systems.

Intellectual merit: This research obtained the first fundamental limits on circuit energy consumption for supporting communication systems at high data rates. These limits apply to any technology, existing or emerging. The research also provided novel and practical flexible strategies for attaining target reliabiliities while keeping energy consumption close to the fundamental limiits. The research also obtained novel strategies for reducing communication overhead in computing for large-scale distributed systems (e.g. cloud computing) and supercomputing. It was demonstrated that there are fundamental tradeoffs between communication complexity, computation complexity, and computation reliabiliity for many algorithms. These algorithms include matrix-multiplication, logistic and linear regression, many machine-learning algorithms, as well as training deep neural networks. The last problem, training deep neural networks on distributed energy-constrained error/fault-prone nodes, had been open since von Neumann's foundational work in 1956. Similarly, matrix-multiplication had been open since Huang and Abraham's revolutionary work in 1984. 

Broader impacts: The PI collaborated with the industry (through SRC's SONIC center) for transferring results of the research into practice. Because matrix multiplication and deep neural networks are workhorses of modern computing systems, performing these computations reliably and efficiently is expected to usher in an era of sustainable Big Data computing. Several undergraduate students, including female and minority students, were trained as a part of this work. The grant also supported 2 female PhD students for a large fraction of their graduate studies. Outreach efforts were organized in collaboration with Gelfand Center for Outreach at CMU, leading to several hands-on workshops and demos for energy-efficiency in Internet-of-Things, demonstrated through a brain-machine interface lab built by the PI. It is expected that one of the undergraduate students trained in this research will launch a startup on Internet-of-Things in the coming year. The PI also gave a tutorial at IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory to disseminate results from this research. The resulting work has received several hundred citations, and has generated substantial interest in both academia and industry.
